hints_html: A light bulb is still working after \(t\) months if and only if it has not failed before \(t\) months.
hints_latex:
A light bulb is still working after $t$ months if and only if it has not
failed before $t$ months.
hints_raw: A light bulb is still working after <math>t </math> months if and only if it has not failed before <math>t </math> months.
question: 5 (c)
sols_html:
The probability that lightbulb \(A\) is still working after \(t\) months is equal to the probability that it has not failed before \(t\) months, which is \(1-F_A(t)= e^{-t}.\)

The probability that lightbulb \(B\) is still working after \(t\) months is equal to the probability that it fails at a time greater than \(t\):

\[\begin{aligned} \int_t^\infty p_B(x)\, dx =2 \int_t^\infty e^{-2x}\, dx =2\left[\frac{e^{-2x}}{-2}\right]_t^\infty = e^{-2t}.\end{aligned}\]

The probability that both lightbulbs are still working after \(t\) months is equal to the product of the two probabilities found above, which is

\[\begin{aligned} e^{-t} e^{-2t}=e^{-3t}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
The probability that lightbulb $A$ is still working after $t$ months is
equal to the probability that it has \textbf{not} failed before $t$
months, which is $1-F_A(t)= e^{-t}.$

The probability that lightbulb $B$ is still working after $t$ months is
equal to the probability that it fails at a time greater than $t$:

\begin{align*}
\int_t^\infty p_B(x)\, dx =2 \int_t^\infty e^{-2x}\, dx =2\left[\frac{e^{-2x}}{-2}\right]_t^\infty = e^{-2t}.
\end{align*}

The probability that \textbf{both} lightbulbs are still working after
$t$ months is equal to the product of the two probabilities found above,
which is

\begin{align*}
e^{-t} e^{-2t}=e^{-3t}.
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
The probability that lightbulb <math>A </math> is still working after <math>t </math> months is equal to the probability that it has '''not''' failed before <math>t </math> months, which is <math> 1-F_A(t)= e^{-t}.</math>

The probability that lightbulb <math>B </math> is still working after <math>t </math> months is equal to the probability that it fails at a time greater than <math>t </math>:

<math> \begin{align} 
\int_t^\infty p_B(x)\, dx =2 \int_t^\infty e^{-2x}\, dx =2\left[\frac{e^{-2x}}{-2}\right]_t^\infty = e^{-2t}.
\end{align}</math>

The probability that  '''both''' lightbulbs are still working after <math>t </math> months is equal to the product of the two probabilities found above, which is

<math> \begin{align} 
e^{-t} e^{-2t}=e^{-3t}.
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
In a room two different lightbulbs \(A\) and \(B\) are installed. According to the packaging, lightbulb \(A\) fails before time \(t\) with probability \(F_A(t)=1-e^{-t}\) (\(t\) in months). Lightbulb \(B\) has a probability density function for the failure time given by \(p_B(t)=Ce^{-2t}.\)

What is the probability that both lightbulbs are still working after \(t\) months?
statement_latex:
In a room two different lightbulbs $A$ and $B$ are installed. According
to the packaging, lightbulb $A$ fails before time $t$ with probability
$F_A(t)=1-e^{-t}$ ($t$ in months). Lightbulb $B$ has a probability
density function for the failure time given by $p_B(t)=Ce^{-2t}.$

What is the probability that both lightbulbs are still working after $t$
months?
statement_raw:
In a  room two different lightbulbs <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> are installed. According to the packaging, lightbulb <math>A</math> fails before time <math>t</math> with probability <math>F_A(t)=1-e^{-t}</math> (<math>t</math> in months). Lightbulb <math>B</math> has a probability density function for the failure time given by <math>p_B(t)=Ce^{-2t}.</math>

What is the probability that both lightbulbs are still working after <math>t</math> months?
